;

;In the field of public opinion, there are two abstract things that are discussed more. One is father, marriage and family; It is private property rights and market economy. Because these two constitute the two indispensable cornerstones of human civilization. Our ability as humans to enter a civilized society really depends on this. This article explores the origin and evolution of these two species from the perspectives of historical genetics and natural evolutionary history.

;

;"Father" is a product of cultural construction

;

;Scholars in the pre-Qin era realized that in the distant "ancient" period, there was no such role as a father. "Zhuangzi: Robber Zhi" states that "in the days of Shen Nong, the people knew their mothers but did not know their fathers." "Lu's Spring and Autumn Annals: Reliance on the King" said: "In ancient times, there were no kings. The people lived in groups and knew each other." "The mother does not know the father", that is, there was no father's role in the "ancient" period, so there was no stable dual family and the corresponding ethics between various relatives.

;

;Professor Wu Fei said that in "Etiquette·Mourning Clothes Biography", "Shang Jun Shu·Kaisa" and "Lu Shi", as well as "Jiao Shi Yi Lin", "Baihu Tong·Hao" and "Lunheng" in the Han Dynasty • Documents such as "Qi Shi" and "He Tu Ting Zuo Fu" all record the situation of "knowing the mother but not knowing the father" in ancient times (Wu Fei: "The "Disintegration" of Human Relations: Anxiety about Family and Country in the Tradition of Moral Theory", Sanlian Bookstore , 2017, pp. 163–166). As a kind of collective memory, as well as field observations of "savages" in the pre-Qin era, we all realize that the role of fathers comes with the development of civilization. This is a consensus among people since the pre-Qin and Han Dynasties.

;

;The "Book of the Later Han Dynasty·Xunli Biography" also noted from the perspective of field observation that the people of Luoyue in the south at that time "had no wedding ceremony laws, and they had no suitable match due to their promiscuity and lust." This state of no stable duality obviously does not produce the role of a father (in a social and cultural sense). Through civilized discipline and education, biological men in nature are transformed into fathers who fulfill family and social responsibilities, thus forming a stable family.

;

;In a stable family structure, bloodline inheritance is clearer, which can encourage fathers to be more actively involved in family and parenting responsibilities. With the father's active participation, the child's survival probability is higher, a stable parent-child relationship is formed, and the child can be with the child for a longer period of time. As a role in this pole of civilization, knowledge that requires longer education and accumulation, including hunting, martial arts, farming, and even a large amount of "tacit knowledge" such as managing a tribe, will be taught to students in the original "family learning" way. child.

;

;To borrow the terminology of the Austrian school of economics, the emergence of the father's role and the dual family, as well as the imagination of the patrilineal ancestral community formed on this basis, are actually the product of super overcoming time preference. In an era without father figures, people consider the time dimension more briefly and often make judgments based on moments or short-term passions. The emergence of the role of fathers and the continuation of stable families and families have made the lines of time extremely long, and people's investment and gaming models also tend to consider the longer future. At this point, savings become more valuable.

;

;People saved grain and raised livestock instead of consuming it immediately. Through savings, children can obtain stable property inheritance. The continuation of private property allows people to "have perseverance and perseverance", overcome time preference, and develop the virtue of accumulating the future. Whether it's working hard to save wealth, or doing good deeds to build a family's reputation, these are the foundations of civilization.

;

;The blood relationship between children and their mothers is natural and does not need to be demonstrated through cultural imagination, but the father is a product of cultural construction and imagination. To imagine community through "patrilineal" requires both the ability to imagine beyond time and abstract cultural construction. Through this model, people who were destined to forget each other in the past can be formed into an imaginary community, creating a close division of labor and collaboration.

;

;Patriline and Aristocracy

;

;Once this kind of family organization is produced, it is destined to have an extremely powerful advantage among the scattered people everywhere who "know their mother but not their father". Many archaeological materials can show that the first to establish a stable dual family order was the earliest aristocratic class. Not only did they create the means of imagining and sustaining community through the patriline, but they also created the earliest surnames.

;

;The "生" in "surname" is a phonetic symbol. The ancient sound of the word "surname" is in the heart mugeng part, and the archaic sound of the word "生" is in the birth mothergeng part. The dental sounds overlap and the pronunciation is basically the same. Therefore, the word "surname" is not interpreted literally as "born by a woman, representing the maternal line." The "female" is only used to label women in the paternal family, and "surname" is used for men in the family. The "生" in the surname is just a phonetic symbol, and the "surname" is just a function of distinguishing between patrilineal families with the same origin and non-intermarriage.

;

;The paternal surname creates a long family tree, which can connect different distant family branches, forming a greater ability to mobilize and cooperate. Therefore, it can be seen that early nobles often prohibited civilians from establishing surnames and did not allow them to establish family trees. For example, in ancient Hawaii, "ordinary civilians were not allowed to record their lineages, and they were prohibited from approaching the supreme chief who was a professional person who recorded the noble lineage. This made the chief and the A sharp separation line was formed between civilians" (Chen Chun: "Exploring the Origins of Civilization and Early States: A Comparison of Chinese and Foreign Theories, Methods and Research", Shanghai Bookstore Press, 2007, p. 246).

;

;The aristocrats and civilians in the Shang Dynasty

;

;From an archaeological point of view, many people in the early days did not have stable paired families, and it was a common phenomenon to not know their mother but their father. For example, in tomb K82.5 at the Wajiaping site of Lintao of the Qijia Culture, an adult woman was buried with a baby under her breast, and the remains of a seven or eight-year-old child. The Qinghai Minhe Lajia F4 abandoned house burial tomb of the Qijia Culture also contains a single woman buried with a child in her arms (Li Xinwei: "Rediscussing the Abandoned House Burial in Prehistoric Period", "Archaeology" 2007 Issue 5, No. Pages 50-56). These single mothers buried alone with their children are a vivid portrayal of the early era of "knowing your mother but not knowing your father".

;

;In the Xiajiadian Dadianzi tombs, there are no couples buried together, and mothers and young children are often buried together. For example, in tomb M30, a mother was buried with two young children, and in M205, a mother was buried with a child. Young children were buried together, M358 was buried with a mother and a child, M675 was buried with a mother and children, M787 was buried with a mother and two infants, and M1246 was buried with a young child (Institute of Archeology, Chinese Academy of Social Sciences: "Dadianzi: Lower Xiajiadian Cultural Sites and Cemetery" Excavation Report", Science Press, 1998, pp. 228-231).

;

;Among the ancient sarcophagus burials of southwestern Yi, there are also tombs in which couples are buried together (Luo Kaiyu: "Research on Sarcophagus Tombs in Western Sichuan and Yunnan and Eastern Tibet", "Acta Archeology", Issue 4, 1992, p. 426 ).

;

;After entering early civilization, nobles had stable couples buried together, but civilians still did not have stable couples buried together. For example, the couple's tombs M303 and M225 of Da Sikong in the Yin Ruins are side by side, 2 meters apart, and they are buried side by side. They are both from the fourth phase of the Yin Ruins, and there are rammed earth buildings on the upper floors (Anyang Working Team of the Institute of Archeology, Chinese Academy of Social Sciences: "Excavation Report of Da Sikong M303 in the Yin Ruins ", "Acta Archeologica Sinica, Issue 3, 2008, p. 388"), this noble tomb has a clear dual relationship.

;

;Meng Xianwu pointed out that two-thirds of the tomb owners in Yinxu did not have a legal spouse during their lifetime. There were not many truly monogamous families. Most of them still lived in unstable couples and incest marriages, so they died. Afterwards, there were no exclusive spouses buried together (Meng Xianwu: "A Review of the Excavations of Tombs in the Southern District of Yin Ruins", "Central Plains Cultural Relics" Issue 3, 1986, p. 80). Some scholars also pointed out that the phenomenon of "burial in different caves" for stable marriages is rare in the Yin Ruins. Throughout the pre-Qin period, single burials of men and women were the main burial method (Yang Baocheng: "Research on Yin Ruins Culture", Wuhan University Press, 2002, pp. 80-83).

;

;From these comprehensive points of view, the common people in the Shang Dynasty still mainly lived in a state without stable couple marriages, while the aristocracy showed a relatively stable couple family. In other words, aristocratic families in the Shang Dynasty had a clear role of "father". The genealogy of the Shang king family in "Historical Records·Yin Benji", as well as the genealogy of the Shang king family presented in the oracle bone inscriptions, and even other signs of noble genealogy found in the oracle bones, such as the famous "Shang Sanjubing" family tree inscription, are all It shows the ability of the aristocracy at that time to construct a community organization in the cultural imaginary way of patriarchy. Although the ties of the ancient clan society had not yet been completely disintegrated at that time, in the oracle bone inscriptions, the children of the Shang family referred to their biological father's brothers of the same generation, that is, uncles, as "father" and "fathers". In addition, the Shang king and queen of Yinxu were also buried in different family cemeteries. "This is probably related to the fact that the blood ties of the clan have not been completely disintegrated." (Anyang Working Team of the Institute of Archeology, Chinese Academy of Social Sciences: "1976 Northwest Xiaotun, Anyang" "Excavation Briefing", "Archaeology", Issue 4, 1987, page 374).

;

;But no matter what, the Shang royal family and other aristocratic families can actually identify their respective biological fathers, and the later the father dies, the more the son succeeds, and the situation of brother's succession is decreasing. . Among the sacrifices, the sacrifices for the biological father are also more solemn. This also shows that the role of "father" in the culture of the royal family and aristocracy of the Shang Dynasty has become more and more clear, while in contrast is the vague civilian class, the mainstream living situation among which is still knowing one's mother but not knowing one's father.

;

;Zhou Civilization and Confucius

;

;By the Zhou Dynasty, the situation of the civilian class had not changed much, while the civilization level of the aristocratic class had further evolved and improved.

;

;At that time, it was said that "propriety is not inferior to common people", that is, the aristocratic class maintained the father and stable couple marriage family structure through civilized "propriety", while the common class continued to know their mother and their father. For example, among the Jin tombs in Chengcun Village, Linyi, Shanxi, among the third-level civilian tombs, couples are rarely found buried in the same cave. "This shows that the burial custom of couples being buried together in caves has not become popular among lower social classes" (Institute of Archeology, Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, etc.: "Linyi Chengcun Cemetery", China Encyclopedia Press, 2003, p. 258 pages).

;

;Scholars pointed out that compared with the Shang Dynasty, it was more common for couples of nobles in the Zhou Dynasty to be buried together in tombs (Zhang Mingdong: "Inspection of Joint Tombs in the Shang and Zhou Dynasties", "Ancient Civilization" Volume 7, Cultural Relics Publishing Society, 2008, p. 185). This also shows that with the development of ritual and music civilization, the civilizational achievements carried by "rituals" more generally covered the families of the aristocratic class at that time. Stable and clear pair marriages, as well as the role of the father, were the further development of civilization in the Zhou Dynasty. important results.

;

;This background actually helps to understand more deeply why Confucius, who lost his father since childhood, had to hold a grand funeral ceremony at the Five Fathers Road after the death of his mother Yan Zheng, and then put her there. He was buried in Fangshan and buried with his father ("Historical Records·Confucius Family"). Because through this act, he can publicly show that he is the child of the aristocratic Kong family, not a "savage" class without a father, but a low-level nobleman with clear parents buried together in the tomb - a scholar.

;

;As an orphan, Confucius never met his father. In fact, what has the greatest influence on him is precisely the maternal family with natural blood connections, that is, his grandfather Yan Xiang and his mother Yan Zheng are in these maternal families. Among the students of Confucius, there were the "Eight Faces of Confucius", namely Yan Lu, Yan Hui, Yan Xing, Yan Gao, Yan Zu, Yan Zhimu, Yan Kuai, and Yan He. Among them, Yan Lu was probably his mother's nephew, that is, Confucius's cousin in his mother's family, and Yan Hui, as the son of Yan Lu, was Confucius's nephew in his mother's family. Confucius' feelings for Yan Hui were often intertwined with the deep emotions of his mother's family, and Yan Hui also regarded Confucius as someone as close to him as his father.

;

;In terms of natural emotions, Confucius actually had the closest relationship with his mother's family, but he knew that the civilized class could not only know its "quality" but not its "culture". "You love his sheep and I love his etiquette." Although my father is far away, he is a symbol of etiquette and civilization. Without the symbol of father, he would remain at the level of knowing his mother and not knowing his father. Therefore, Confucius chose to publicly bury his mother and father together, declaring that he was the successor of Uncle Liang He, the official of Zouyi, and inherited and continued his father's "Kong" surname. The origin of the patrilineal imaginary community can therefore be traced back to the monarchs of the ancient Song Dynasty, and even the more distant Shang royal family, and all the way back to the emperor Ku and other figures in the ancient mythological era.

;

;Confucius' recognition of his ancestors opened a path to encourage the common people to imitate the nobility, to go beyond knowing their mother and not knowing their father, and to establish a clear father's family like the aristocrats. Confucius not only recruited a large number of elite children of civilians, but also spread aristocratic knowledge to them. Confucianism in later generations also encouraged civilians to learn etiquette, become civilized people, become qualified fathers, and imitate the nobles in establishing surnames, family trees, and family temples. The establishment and recognition of the father's symbol is an important springboard to civilization.

;

;Small communities and private property rights

;

;By clarifying the role of the father and the cultural construction of the family, it provides an accumulated foundation for the development of communities and private property. The family is the foundation of private property rights, and private property rights are an important cornerstone of civilization. Only on this foundation does it make sense to save and develop for the future. It is on the basis of private property rights that the principle of "differentiated love" can bring into play the interactive effect of communities of different circles.

;

;Private property rights are not actually "private" as understood by Yang Zhu's atomic individuals. In a private property society, various forms of property sharing are actually practiced within families. The traditional primogeniture system in Western Europe retains the integrity of family property, although the second son can only receive an annuity provided by his elder brother, or even has no property and can only go out to explore the world. However, the family property is not "privately owned" by the atomic individual of the eldest son, but is the custodian between the ancestors and descendants of the blood community, so the property still belongs to the community.

;

;In contrast, the Chinese are more inclined to divide property. In addition to other scholars, according to the law of the Song Dynasty, "a woman can marry half of a man", and daughters can also get the right to inherit family property. On the one hand, Confucians encourage the formation of clan communities with more levels of property distribution without dividing families, or by establishing family common property trusts such as "Fan's Yizhuang" and "clan fields", "sacrifice fields" and "school fields" that are common in South China. " and so on, maintaining various forms of common property of small communities.

;

;The meaning of private property rights is mainly the defense mechanism that must be in place when facing public power representing the greater community. That is to say, the property rights of small communities such as families and families cannot be infringed on in the name of a large community or a society of strangers. In the face of public rights, private property rights are embodied as "private", but within small communities, they are mostly represented as "public" with various tender feelings.

;

;Even in the British Victorian era, which was criticized by some people, while the market economy and industrialization were highly developed, family values ​​remained strong, providing warmth and a haven to escape the cruelty of society. The song "Home, Sweet Home" written by John Howard Payne in 1822 has been popular in the English-speaking world for more than a hundred years. It sings: "Home, home, sweet, sweet home! There is no place like home in the world. A better place”. The popularity of this song just shows that the high development of the market economy at that time did not destroy family values. On the contrary, it highlighted the "privacy" of the family as a small community and its positive role in protecting people.

;

;The development of market economy

;

;On the basis of private property rights, especially with the further development of the industrial and commercial economy, there is a need for rich exchanges and cooperation between strangers from all over the world. At this time, the market economy based on private property rights was nurtured and developed, and through various business models such as games and cooperation based on property rights, the lowest-cost method of cooperation between strangers in a complex society was realized.

;

;In a free market economy, various small communities can divide labor and collaborate more effectively. As the market order expands, the number of groups it absorbs further increases, the division of labor is continuously refined, efficiency increases and costs decrease, forming a positive-sum game effect, and people benefit together.

;

;Under the collaboration model of the market economy, people have also learned to trade and collaborate in ways that go beyond traditional small communities. With the improvement of life and the abundance of commodities, more ordinary people have the opportunity to have access to the culture and art of past elites at low cost. Ludwig von Mises said: "If an argument is needed, it is only necessary to point out how serious music has become popular in the past few decades, especially among those who are busy in business. That's enough. There has never been a time in history when art has been brought so close to the hearts of so many people" ([Austrian] Ludwig von Mises: "Socialism: Economic and Sociological Analysis", Translated by Wang Jianmin et al., China Social Sciences Press, 2008, p. 406).

;

;In the past, classical books were extremely expensive in China, and there were many records in the literature of "poor families without books". According to the "Book of the Northern Qi Dynasty: Du Bi's Biography", his grandfather was the governor of Huainan and his father was the county magistrate, but his family was still "poor and without books". "Yan's Family Instructions Encouraging Learning" specifically emphasizes, "If you can always keep hundreds of volumes of books, you will never be a villain for thousands of years." As long as the family can keep some precious books, there will not be a class decline, but it will be able to continue. Stay in the elite class.

;

;However, with the advent of the Song Dynasty, driven by the market economy, commercial book engraving began to rise and flourish, and a large number of high-end classical books began to enter the lives of ordinary people. Su Dongpo mentioned: "When I met the old Confucian Mr. Yu, I said that when I was young, I wanted to get "Historical Records" and "Han Shu" but could not get them. Fortunately, I got them. I wrote them by myself and read them day and night, for fear of not being able to catch up. In recent years, people in the city have turned around. The books of hundreds of schools of thought were copied from each other, and thousands of pieces of paper were passed down every day. The books written by scholars were numerous and easy to produce" ("Li's Shanfang Collection Secretary").

;

;Here, it is precisely because "city people" "copied" driven by commercial interests that caused the rapid popularity of classical books, and a large number of classical books entered the world of ordinary people. In the past in Europe, Stoic books and Rococo art were limited to a limited number of aristocratic elites and out of reach of ordinary civilians. However, with the development of market economy and industrialization, production costs have been greatly reduced, and ordinary workers can also hang a print of a Leonardo da Vinci or Van Gogh painting at home, or collect an industrially produced classical book. The market economy allows the aristocratic culture and elite rituals and music that were once aloof to enter the families and lives of ordinary people more efficiently, raising the average level of civilized society.

;

;It can be said that from the perspective of historical genetics and natural evolutionary history, the emergence of the stable dual family, the role of "father" (in a cultural sense) and the marriage system, as well as the emergence of the marriage system based on this Private property rights and market economy are the two cornerstones of a civilized society.
